title: The pilgrim's wallet;
author: Haven, Gilbert
snippet: Two of the streets attract your chief attention. The Avenue de ITmpera trice, that of the Empress, runs out of the city to the Bois de Boulogne, the park of Paris. It is three hundred feet wide, straight as an arrow, and hard as marble.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: The Place du Chatelet is where once stood the notorious prison ofthe Chatelet, but the place is now occupied by the Fountain of Victory,with figures representing Fidelity, Vigilance, Justice, and Power; the'figure on the top represents Victory distributing laurels. The Avenue del'Opera, the finest thoroughfare in Paris, three-quarters of a mile in length,was until recently a collection of small gloomy streets, which the fires ofthe Commune helped to clear away. This avenue was at one time lightedby electricity, but the electric lights have been replaced by gas lamps.

title: Travels in Europe and Northern Africa.
author: Rose, W. G.
snippet: Near it is the Parliament, or Reichstag, Building, with gilded dome. The Avenue of Victory is through a park, and is ornamented with many statues, some of which are placed upon a crescent-shaped base of marble with a seat encircling one side, giving an appearance  of hospitality. In a carriage ride we passed the City Hall, a magnificent structure in red brick, and miles of residences of light-brown color.
